title: Between 1 January 2018 and 31 December 2018, will an armed group from Sudan engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Sudan?
preds: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Integer nec odio. Praesent libero. Sed cursus ante dapibus diam. Sed nisi. Nulla quis sem at nibh elementum imperdiet. Duis sagittis ipsum. Praesent mauris. Fusce nec tellus sed augue semper porta. Mauris massa. Vestibulum lacinia arcu eget nulla. Class aptent taciti sociosqu ad litora torquent per conubia nostra, per inceptos himenaeos.
That place is pretty wild right now.
There is financial opportunity in wartime and that is the only reason to be in South Sudan.  The fighting there will stop when everyone on both sides is dead.
The continuing government process will probably accomplish this threshold by Q2 2018.

Of the Northern African countries undergoing armed conflict Sudan and South Sudan are still the most likely to see systematic killing of civilians.  The Sudanese government has already demonstrated a willingness to carry out such a campaign and the two ongoing conflicts in the country are as yet unresolved.

Of course at this point, it is way too early to give anything above 10% probability. However, factoring in the water crisis currently happening in South Africa, a much more politically stable country, and that this year will most likely (<95%) be the warmest year on record, I must give more credence (25%-29%) that a major conflict in Sudan (where water has been an resource issue for some time) can break out this year, the likelihood of an armed group engaging in wanton killing seems like a possibility in the 15%-25% chance range, but systematic execution of civilians requires an ideology that only a group like the Janjiweed once had, i.e. a fundamentalist group.

Going down to 3%. With South Sudan a mess, believe border issues are quiet for now - there is disrupted over several cities, oil fields, and parks I believe. Dictator Bashir mostly keeping head down - but is providing Saudis support in Yemen (last I knew) so he has a few friends on the continent (South Africa as well who wouldn’t hand him over re. Darfur). He runs a fairly tight security apparatus so don’t see any internal actors pushing an event that would lead to 1000 civilian deaths.
Terrorist groups are retrenching and in desperate need of outside financing. Lower than usual activities.
The P(A|B) for insurgent attacks by domestic groups engaging in Collective Action outcomes with fatalities or successful attacks in Sudan for 2018 = .0 to this date.
Every report that I've seen has indicated that all of the trouble is in South Sudan; despite the undesirable government in Sudan, it seems reasonably stable.
Agree with most of the others here. While unstable etc. Citizenry can look at South Sudan and know they want to avoid that... ruling party doesn’t broker much dissent.
After the secession of South Sudan the main potential of conflict is gone and Sudan currently is going through a phase of consolidation.
HIGHLY UNSTABLE COUNTRY WITH WEAK GOVERNMENTAL CONTROLS OVER THEIR CITIZENRY.
With unresolved issues in Darfur, this is highly likely.
Lack of conflict resolution and ongoing ethic inequalities fueling negative emotions among groups due to ineffective communication caused by incomplete bilateral perception deficits.
